title: Sleep Optimization for Peak Ultra Performance
summary: Evidence-based sleep strategies to maximize recovery and race-day performance.
body:
# Sleep Optimization for Ultras

Sleep is your most powerful recovery tool. Here's how to optimize it for ultra training and racing.

## The Science

**What Happens During Sleep:**
- Growth hormone release (muscle repair)
- Glycogen replenishment
- Immune system strengthening
- Neural pathway consolidation
- Inflammation reduction

**Research shows:**
- <7 hours sleep = 30% increased injury risk
- Poor sleep = reduced time to exhaustion
- Sleep debt accumulates and can't be "caught up" on weekends

## Training Phase Sleep Targets

### Base Building
- **Target:** 8-9 hours nightly
- **Why:** Maximum adaptation to aerobic stimulus
- **Priority:** Consistency over quantity

### Build/Peak Weeks
- **Target:** 9+ hours nightly
- **Why:** Harder training requires more recovery
- **Strategy:** Add 30-60 min nap on hard training days

### Taper
- **Target:** 8-9 hours (same as base)
- **Why:** Sleep debt repayment, nervous system priming
- **Note:** Don't oversleep—disrupts circadian rhythm

## Sleep Hygiene Protocols

### 3 Hours Before Bed
- Finish eating (digestion disrupts sleep)
- Limit fluids (reduce bathroom trips)
- No alcohol (ruins REM sleep)

### 1 Hour Before Bed
- Dim lights (triggers melatonin)
- Cool room to 65-68°F
- Blue light blocking (glasses or screen filters)
- Light reading or meditation

### Bedtime
- Same time every night (±30 min)
- Dark room (blackout curtains or eye mask)
- White noise if needed
- No phone in bedroom

## Race Week Sleep Strategy

**Days 7-3 Before Race:**
- Maintain normal schedule
- 8-9 hours nightly
- Avoid sleep debt

**Days 2-1 Before Race:**
- Don't stress about poor sleep (normal pre-race anxiety)
- Focus on relaxation over forcing sleep
- The sleep 2 nights before matters most

**Race Night (for 100M):**
- If racing through night, nap 2-3 hours in afternoon
- Don't change sleep schedule week before

## Common Mistakes

❌ Training late (within 3 hours of bedtime)
❌ Inconsistent sleep schedule
❌ Alcohol to "help" sleep
❌ Overthinking one bad night
❌ Napping too late (after 3 PM)

## When to Nap

**Best practices:**
- 20-30 min power nap (avoid sleep inertia)
- Between 1-3 PM (aligns with circadian dip)
- After hard workouts
- Never as replacement for nightly sleep

**The Bottom Line:** Treat sleep as seriously as your training. It's not recovery if you're not sleeping.
author: Coach Brandon
